author: Unexpected Sounds

comment: This is a really nice example, but you ought to check out the Jefferson Golden Hour clock. It uses a counterweight so that neither hand has to be attached to the bezel or mechanism at all. They're quite elegant and you don't see anything moving since it's all actually hidden. They were in production from 1949 until 1991; my parents received one as a wedding gift in 1954 and I still have it, plus a couple more, as well as a few examples of the other clocks in the Jefferson lineup. There were around 7 models, some available in different finishes, and a couple employed different mechanics to create the illusion.

Nice variation on a Jefferson Golden Hour Mystery Clock (which I have).  The Jefferson has just a motor and the minute hand is geared to the hour hand which is locked to a glass disc that rotates smoothly without steps.

comment:
First of all, this is a very cool end result and really nice of you to share it with us. I watched it and was moved to think about how I could do similar things, and it was informative about the steps involved and had a pleasant end result.  So my concerns below are about replicating the same project in my own life:

It's pretty cool that it is possible to order a PCB board starting at $0 if someone has the time to design it themselves.  For the part where you design a gerber file for a custom PCB -  for someone who's never designed a gerber file like me, and has other responsibilities and doesn't yet know electronics, I looked up how many hours it would take to get to the level of competence to do this without any outsourcing, and it seems to be about 160-240 which is about 4-8 weeks full time.  It it possible for anyone to learn these skills if they have the time to fit it into their life.

In my case I would be inclined to use Fiverr to speed up the custom PCB creation step which is not an option right now, however I think it is important to be realistic and strategically work with other designers such as on CAD files for 3D printing and on PCB design.  The idea itself is really cool, and I am impressed by the finished product and thankful that you shared it.

Mind blown!!! 

Recently I saw a similar looking ring-clock but in a more classic fassion: there was a static vertical bar comming from the top of the ring to the center, holding a regular clock mechanism. author: Cloudy

comment:
I'm wondering if there's a way to make both hands magnetic, or if the magnetic fields will just be too likely to overlap whenever the minute hand passes over the hour hand. Maybe with a buffer zone between the two... but then, of course, you'd need something else to hold up the center point, negating the premise of the "hollow" clock. I mean, it's still pretty impressive looking even if you use a clear background, you just can't put your hand through it... But then, if both hands used magnets, you could completely hide the mechanical workings of the clock (right now, you can still see the circles turning if you know where to look).

I'm might be having way too much fun backseat engineering this clock, heh. The current product is amazingly cool as is, it's just that to my brain, once I saw the magnet solution for the hour hand... whelp.
